Description: Al Kaline is a former American baseball player. He played his entire twenty-two year career with the Detroit Tigers. Kaline won the Golden Glove award ten times, he is an eighteen time all star, and a World Series champion.
Sculptor: Omri Amrany, Julie Rotblatt Amrany, & Lou Cella

Description: Al Lopez was a Spanish-American baseball player. He played from 1927 to 1948 and he played for the Brooklyn Robins/Dodgers, Boston Bees, Pittsburgh Pirates, and the Cleveland Indians. In addition to being a successful player, he was also a team manager for the Cleveland Indians and the Chicago White Sox.

Allen Iverson is a former American professional basketball player. He played in the league for fourteen seasons and in that time he won many rewards. He was Rookie of the Year in 1997, He is an 11-time All Star, was the NBA's MVP in 2001. He was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2016.

Althea Gibson is an American former tennis player and golfer. She was the first African American athlete to cross the color line in tennis and she was the first African American player to win a Grand Slam title. She changed the game of tennis and blazed a trail for the women of color who came after her.
Location: USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center

Description: Annie Oakley was an American former shooter and performer. She began shooting when she was a teenager as a means to help support her family. She eventually entered into a shooting contest where she met her future husband, Frank butler. Oakley and Butler joined a various Wild West shows and performed across the country. Oakley_s statue stands in Annie Oakley Memorial Park in Greenville, Ohio, the city where Oakley was born.

Arnold Palmer was an American professional golfer. He was nicknamed _the King_ and was one of the biggest stars in the early years of televised sports in the 1950s. Palmer won the PGA Tour 62 times; he won the PGA Tour Champions ten times, and the European Tour two times.

Arthur Ashe was an American tennis player. Ashe played tennis from 1969 to his retirement in 1980. Ashe is the first African American man to win the singles title at Wimbledon, the U.S. Open, and the Australian Open. Ashe was an outspoken civil rights supporter and activist.

Babe Ruth was an American former baseball player. He played for twenty-two seasons in the MLB, from 1914 to 1935. Ruth played for the Boston Red Sox and Boston Braves but gained notoriety during his time with the New York Yankees. He was a two-time All Star, a seven-time World Series champion, and a twelve-time American League home run leader.

Ben Hogan was an American golfer who was best known for his swing and ability to strike the ball in a particular way. He became a professional in 1930 and retired in 1971. Hogan was inducted into the Golf Hall of Fame in 1974. He was the PGA Player of the Year four times and the Associated Press_ Male Athletes of the Year in 1953.

Bill Russell is an American former basketball player and coach. He played for the Boston Celtics from 1956 to 1969 and has been routinely named as one of the greatest players of all time. Russell was one of the first African American players to really achieve superstar status in the NBA. He is an eleven time NBA champion, a twelve time All Star, and a five time NBA Most Valuable Player.

Billy Kidd is an American former World Cup alpine ski racer. He was also a part of the Olympic team and has won four medals over his career. One of the medals is from the 1964 Olympic games in Austria and the other three were earned at World Championships. Kidd_s statue is located at the Steamboat Ski Resort in Colorado, where he continues to work as a director.

Bob Cousy is a former American basketball player. Cousy played most of his career with the famed Boston Celtics from 1950 to 1963. Cousy played at Holy Cross where he became an NCAA champion. He later became a six time NBA champion, NBA Most Valuable Player, and a thirteen time NBA all star.

Bob Feller was an American baseball player who played for the Cleveland Indians from 1936 to 1956. Feller was a pitcher and was nicknamed _The Heater from Van Meter_ and _Bullet Bob._ He was an eight time all star, a World Series Champion, and he pitched three no hitters.
Bob Hoffman rose to prominence as a weightlifter and sport entrepreneur. He coached the Olympic weightlifting team from 1936 to 1968. He ultimately moved from weightlifting to bodybuilding.

Bobby Orr is a former Canadian hockey player who played in the NHL for twelve seasons. He played ten seasons with the Boston Bruins and two seasons with the Chicago Black Hawks. Orr took the Bruins to their first championship in franchise history and they won two Stanley Cup titles while he was on the team.

Brandi Chastain is a fromer member of the 1999 Women_s World Cup soccer team. She scored the winning goal in the penalty kick shootout against China at the Rose Bowl in Los Angeles, California. She was inducted into the National Soccer Hall of Fame in 2017.

Brooks Robinson is an American retired baseball player. HE played for twenty-two seasons for the Baltimore Orioles, from 1966 to 1977. Robinson is an eighteen-time All Star, a two-time World Series champion, and a sixteen-time Gold Glove award winner.

Cal Ripken Jr. is an American retired baseball player. He played for a total of twenty-one seasons for the Baltimore Orioles from 1981 to 2001. Ripken played shortstop and third base and he still holds the record for most homeruns by a short stop.

Cal Ripken Jr. is a nineteen time All Star, a World Series champion, and a two-time Gold Glove Award winner. He was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 2007 and the Baltimore Orioles retired his number in 2001.

Carl Lewis is an American former Track and Field athlete. Lewis won a total of twenty-eight medals throughout his career; ten Olympic medals, ten World Championship medals, three medals at the Pan American Games, and five medals at the Goodwill Games. He is one of only three Olympic athletes to win gold medals in the same event at four consecutive Olympics.

Carl Yastrzemski is a former American baseball player. Yastrzemski played his entire baseball career with the Boston Red Sox from 1961 to 1983. Yastrzemski is an eighteen time all-star, an American League Most Valuable Player, and seven-time Gold Glove award winner. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1989.

Cy Young was an American professional baseball player. He played in the league from 1890 to 1911 for the Cleveland Spiders, St. Louis Perfectos/Cardinals, Boston Americans/Red Sox, Cleveland Naps, and the Boston Rustlers. He was a World Series champion, a two-time strikeout leader, and a two-time ERA leader.

Earnhardt is known as one of the most prolific NASCAR drivers in racing history. He won a total of 76 Winston Cup races. In 2001 Earnhardt died due to complications he suffered in a crash during the final lap of the Daytona 500. _Dale Earnhardt.
Dale Earnhardt Sr. was an American professional auto-racing driver. Earnhardt is best known for his stock car racing in NASCAR. He was inducted into the NASCAR Hall of Fame in 2001.

Dan Marino is a former American football player who played for the Miami Dolphins for seventeen seasons. Marino was the starting quarterback for the Dolphins from 1983 to 1999. Marino is a nine time pro bowl selection, an NFL Most Valuable Player, and a five time NFL passing yards leader.

Doug Flutie is a former American football player and he played football from 1981 to 2005. His famed career started at Boston College where he won the Heisman Trophy in 1985. He was drafted 285th overall in the NFL draft, making him the lowest drafted Heisman Trophy winner to date. He ultimately signed with the Los Angeles Rams and was traded to the Chicago Bears almost immediately. He went on to play in the Canadian League and eventually ended his career in 2005 with the New England Patriots.

Dutch Clark was an American former football player and coach. He played for the Portsmouth Spartans/Detroit Lions from 1931 to 1938. Clark was among the first to be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1951 and was among the first selections to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1963. He was an NFL champion, a six-time First-Team All Pro selection, and a three-time NFL rushing touchdown leader.

Earl Campbell is an American former football player. He played professionally for the Houston Oilers and the New Orleans Saints from 1978 to 1985. His played his college career at the University of Texas, where he won the Heisman trophy in 1977. His statue stands outside of Darrell K. Royal-Texas Memorial Stadium at the University of Texas in Austin.
Location: Darrell K Royal-Texas Memorial Stadium at University of Texas, Austin

Description: Eddie Murray is an American retired baseball player. Murray was nicknamed _Steady Eddie_ and spent twenty seasons in the MLB. He played from 1977 to 1997 for various clubs including the Baltimore Orioles, Los Angeles Dodgers, New York Mets, Cleveland Indians, and Anaheim Angels. He is an eight-time All Star, a World Series champion, and three-time Gold Glove award winner.

Elgin Baylor is an American former basketball player, who eventually became a coach and executive in the NBA. He played a total of fourteen seasons for the Minneapolis/Los Angeles Lakers franchises. He is an eleven time NBA All Star, an NBA All Star Game Most Valuable Player, and a ten time All-NBA First Team selection.

Enos Slaughter was an American baseball player who played 19 seasons in the MLB. He was a ten time all star, a four-time World Series champion, and has been elected to the National Baseball Hall of Fame.

Ernie Banks was an American baseball player. Banks played both first base and shortstop for the Chicago Cubs. Banks was nicknamed _Mr. Cub_ and played for the ball club from 1953 to 1971. Banks was a fourteen time all star, a two time National League Most Valuable Player, and a two-time National League homerun leader.

Ernie Davis was an American football player. He had a successful college career at Syracuse where he won the Heisman Trophy in 1961; he was the first African American person to with the award. He was the first pick in the 1961 draft by the Washington Redskins, but was immediately traded to the Cleveland Browns. Davis was diagnosed with leukemia in 1962 and died before he even got to play a single professional game.

Florence Griffith Joyner was an American Track and Field athlete. She is widely considered the fastest woman in the world and still holds the records for the 100 and 200-meter races, records that she set in 1988. Griffith Joyner competed in both the Seoul and Los Angeles Olympics; she won three gold medals and one silver in Seoul and one silver medal in Los Angeles.

Frank Howard is an American former baseball player, coach, and manager. He played in the MLB from 1958 to 1973 for the Los Angeles Dodgers, Washington Senators/Texas Rangers, and the Detroit Tigers. He is a four time All Star, a World Series Champion, and a two-time American League home run leader.

Frank Robinson was an American baseball player. He played for twenty seasons, from 1956 to 1976. He is the only player to be named Most Valuable Player on teams in both the American and National League. Robinson is a fourteen time All Star, a two-time World Series champion, and a National League Rookie of the Year. He was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1982.

Frank White Jr. is an American former baseball player. He played in the MLB for eighteen seasons for the Kansas City Royals. White is a five time All Star, a World Series champion, and an eight time Gold Glove award winner.

George Brett is an American former baseball player. He played twenty one seasons in the MLB and he played his whole career for the Kansas City Royals. Brett is a thirteen-time All Star selection, a World Series Most Valuable Player, and an American League Most Valuable Player.

George Woolf was a Canadian born thoroughbred racehorse jockey. Woolf is bet known for his 1938 race when he rode Seabiscuit to victory over a heavily favored horse at the Pimlico special in Baltimore. Over his career Woolf won ninety-seven major races in the United States.

Haeng Ung Lee was born in Manchuria, China in 1936. In 1956 Lee entered the Korean Army as a martial arts trainer and three years later he opened a Taekwondo school at the American air base, Osan Air Base. In 1969, Lee founded the American Taekwondo Association. After becoming an American citizen in 1973, Lee received various awards for business, civic activities, and his continued to commitment to the martial arts. In 1999, Lee escorted martial arts instructors into North Korea as an attempt to encourage peace between the two countries.
Gretchen Fraser was an American alpine skier. Fraser was the first American Olympian to win a gold medal in skiing. She won the medal in 1948.
Gretchen Fraser was an American alpine skier. Fraser was the first American Olympian to win a gold medal in skiing. She won the medal in 1948.

Hank Aaron is an American former baseball player. He played twenty-one seasons in the MLB from 1954 to 1976 and he played for the Milwaukee/Atlanta Braves and the Milwaukee Brewers. Before embarking on his MLB career, Aaron played one season in the Negro Leagues for the Indianapolis Clowns. He is a twenty-five time All Star, a World Series champion, and a National League Most Valuable Player.

Harmon Killebrew was an American baseball player. He played first base, third base, and left field. Killebrew played for the Minnesota Twins, the Washington Senators, and the Kansas City Royals. He was a thirteen time all star, a six-time American League home run leader and a three time American League runs batted in (RBI) leader.

Harold _Red_ Grange was an American football player. He played for the University of Illinois and the Chicago Bears. In 2008 he was named the best college player of all time by ESPN. Grange was a two-time NFL champion, Big Ten Most Valuable Player, and three time All American.

Harold Baines is a former American Baseball player who played for the Chicago White Sox, Texas Rangers, Oakland Athletics, Baltimore Orioles, and the Cleveland Indians. Baines is a six time all star, a World Series champion, and has been inducted into the Baltimore Orioles Hall of Fame. He coached the Chicago White Sox from 2005 to 2014 and ultimately became a spring training instructor for the team.

Harry Agganis was an American baseball player. He played two seasons for the Boston Red Sox from 1954 to 1955; he became gravely ill in 1955 and eventually died of a pulmonary embolism. Before embarking on his professional baseball career, Agganis played collegiate football at Boson University and he became the first All-American.

J.P. Honus Wagner was an American former baseball player. Wagner played twenty-one seasons in the MLB; he played from 1987 to 1917. He was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1936; he was one of its first five members. Wagner is a World Series champion, an eight time National League batting champion, and a five time National League stolen base leader.

Jack Johnson was an American boxer who became the first African American world heavyweight champion. In 1910 Johnson defeated James Jeffries in what was called the _fight of the century._ Johnson became the most famous athlete in the United States and became part of the larger legacy of racism during the Jim Crow era. Johnson_s confident demeanor in the face of such racism did not bode well for the athlete as he was arrested and eventually had to spend time in prison due to racist laws regarding his relations with white women. Johnson fought a total of 104 fights and lost only 13 of those contests.

In 1922 Jack Trice became the first African American football player at Iowa State University. He died in 1923 after complications from a hit that he sustained during a game against the University of Minnesota. Trice_s death highlighted the violence in football and some teammates suggested that the hit on Trice was racially motivated. 
In 1997 the football stadium the Iowa State University was officially named Jack Trice Stadium, making it the only division one football stadium named after an African American person.

Jackie Robinson was an American baseball player who became the first African American person to play in the MLB. Robinson was chosen from the Negro Leagues and recruited by the Brooklyn ball club, the Montreal Royals. The general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, Branch Rickey, made a point to try and rile Robinson up with racial comments just to see if he could take it in the major leagues.

The Jackie Robinson statue at the Dodger_s Stadium was dedicated in the spring of 2017. The statue is the first to be erected at the famed stadium. The day of the dedication was April 15, 2017 and this marks the sixty-year anniversary of when Robinson broke the color line in the MLB.

On April 18, 1926 Jackie Robinson ushered in the integrated era of baseball. This game was Robinson_s professional debut with the Montreal Royals and was against the Jersey City Giants. A year later Robinson would be called up to Brooklyn where he would break the major league color line.
The Jackie Robinson statue at the Rose Bowl was unveiled in November of 2017. The statue depicts Robinson in his football uniform to celebrate his playing career at UCLA.

The Jackie Robinson statue at UCLA is located outside of the Jackie Robinson baseball stadium. While attending UCLA Robinson became the first person to letter in four varsity sports: baseball, track, basketball, and football. While Robinson played for UCLA, it was the most integrated football team in all of college football.

James Brendan Connolly was an American Olympic athlete. Connolly competed in the first iteration of the modern Olympic games in 1896 in Athens where he won three medals; a gold I the triple jump, a silver in the high jump, and a bronze in the long jump. He competed in the 1900 Olympics in Paris and won a silver medal in the triple jump.

Jeff Bagwell is a former American baseball player who played his entire fifteen-year career for the Houston Astros. Bagwell played first base for the Astros from 1991 to 2005. Bagwell was a four time all star, the National League Most Valuable player, and three-time Silver Slugger award.

Jerry West is an American former Basketball player. He played in the NBA from 1960 to 1974 for the Los Angeles Lakers. He is a fourteen time All Star, an NBA Finals Most Valuable Player, and an NBA championship. After his retirement, West became a coach and later, an executive.

Jesse Owens_ success at the Berlin Olympics was touted as a global victory. Owens competed in front of Hitler, who had organized the Olympics in Germany and not only did he win four gold medals and set three world records, but he debunked Hitler_s notions of racial inferiority in front of the world. Owens is still one of the most celebrated athletes of all time and has been dubbed as one of the greatest athletes of all time.

Jesse Owens was an American track and field and Olympic athlete. Owens is best known for his performance at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin. He won a total of four gold medals in the 100-meter, the 200-meter, the 4 x 100 meter relay, and the long jump.

Jim Palmer is an American retired baseball player. He played a total of nineteen seasons for the Baltimore Orioles, from 1965 to 1984. Palmer is a six-time All Star, a three-time World Series champion, and a four-time Gold Glove Award winner. He was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1990.

Jim Thorpe was an American athlete who played football, baseball, basketball, and competed in the decathlon and pentathlon. Thorpe is the first Native person to win an Olympic gold medal. He won gold medals in the pentathlon and decathlon at the Stockholm Olympics in 1912.

Jimmie Foxx was an American baseball player from 1925 to 1945. He played for the Philadelphia Athletics, Boston Red Sox, Chicago Cubs, and the Philadelphia Phillies. Foxx was a nine-time All Star, a two-time World Series champion, and a three-time American League Most Valuable Player.

Joe Dimaggio was an American baseball player. He played his entire thirteen-year career for the New York Yankees. Dimaggio is regarded as one of the best players to ever play professionally and he is best known for his 56 game hitting streak. He was a thirteen time all star, a nine-time World Series champion, and a three time American League Most Valuable Player.
Location: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame

Description: Joe Frazier was an American boxer; he was the heavyweight champion from 1970 to 1973. His most famous fights were against George Foreman and Muhammad Ali. He beat Ali in 1971 at what was dubbed, _fight of the century,_ and then lost his title to Foreman in1973.
Joe Louis is an American boxer who competed from 1934-1951. Louis was the reigning world champion from 1937 to 1949 and has been become one of the greatest boxers of all time.

The Monument to Joe Louis is located in Detroit_s Hart Plaza. The monument depicts a twenty-four foot long forearm and fist that is meant to symbolize Louis_ dominance in the sport of boxing. The fist was dedicated in 1986 and remains a contested work of art within the city.
John B. Kelly was an American rower. He became the first three time Olympic champion in American rowing.

John Stockton is an American former basketball player. He played his entire nineteen-season career with the Utah Jazz and is widely regarded as one of the greatest point guards. He still holds the record for most career assists and most steals. Stockton is a two-time NBA champion, a ten time NBA All Star, and a two time NBA Fist Team selection. _John Stockton.
Johnny Unitas was a three-time NFL champion, a ten time Pro Bowl selection, and an NFL Man of the Year.

Johnny Unitas was an American football player. He played professionally from 1956 to 1973 and he played most of his career with the Baltimore Colts. He held the record for most consecutive games with a touchdown pass for 52 years, until Drew Brees surpassed him in 2012.

Josh Gibson was one of the greatest baseball players to play in the Negro leagues. He began his career with the Homestead Grays in Pennsylvania and also played for the Pittsburgh Crawfords. He later played for the Mexican and Dominican Leagues and even became a manager for the Puerto Rican team, the Santruce Crabbers. He was a twelve time all star and a two-time Negro World Series champion. In 1972, Gibson became the second player from the Negro Leagues to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
Joy Selig is a former collegiate gymnast at Oregon State University. She competed in the floor exercise and the balance beam.

Judy Johnson was an American baseball player in the Negro leagues from 1921-1937. Johnson, who was a third baseman, was part of the Pittsburgh Crawfords in 1935, which was widely regarded as the greatest team in Negro League history. Johnson was a two-time all star and a Negro Leagues champion. In 1975 he was elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

Julius Erving, also known as _Dr.J,_ is an American former basketball player. He played from 1971 to 1987 in both the American Basketball Association (ABA) and the National Basketball Association (NBA). He is an NBA champion, an eleven-time All Star selection, and a two-time ABA champion. Erving was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is an American former basketball player. He played for twenty seasons for both the Milwaukee Bucks and the Los Angeles Lakers. He played for UCLA from 1966 to 1969 and was selected first overall in the NBA draft. Abdul-Jabbar is a six time NBA champion, a six time NBA Most Valuable Player, and a nineteen time All Star. He has always been an outspoken civil rights supporter and activist.

Karl Malone is an American former basketball player. He played from 1985 to 2004 and he played the bulk of his career for the Utah Jazz. He was a two time NBA Most Valuable Player, a fourteen time NBA All Star, and an eleven time NBA First Team selection. _Karl Malone.

Ken Griffey Jr. is a former American baseball player. He played for 22 seasons in the MLB and was a 13 time all star in the league. Griffey Jr. is known as one of the greatest homerun hitters to play with 630 home runs, he is ranked seventh all time in homeruns.

Kirby Puckett was an American baseball player. He played his entire career as a center fielder for the Minnesota Twins. Puckett was a ten time all star, a two time World Series champion, and a six time Silver Slugger award.

Kobe Bryant, also known as the Black Mamba, played for the Los Angeles Lakers for the entirety of his career, from 1996 to 2016. Bryant was an 18 time All Star, he won 5 Championships, and competed on Team USA in the 2008 and 2012 Olympics. Bryant died in a tragic helicopter accident on 2020. That same year, he was posthumously selected to enter the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame.

Larry Bird is an American former basketball player, coach, and executive. He played for the Boston Celtics for the entirety of his thirteen-year career. Bird went on to coach the Indiana Pacers for three years and won Coach of the Year in 1998. Bird was a three time NBA champion, a two time Finals Most Valuable Player, and a three time NBA Most Valuable Player.

Larry Holmes is an American former boxer. He competed from 1973 to 2002 and he fought a total of seventy-five matches, he won sixty-nine of them and lost on six. Holmes held the heavyweight title from 1978 to 1983 and he holds the record for the longest individual heavyweight streak.

Magic Johnson is an American former basketball player. He played for a total of thirteen seasons all for the Los Angeles Lakers. He is a five time NBA champion, a three time NBA Finals Most Valuable Player, and a twelve time NBA All Star. Johnson has also been a coach and President of Basketball Operations in the NBA.

Magic Johnson played for Michigan State University from 1977 to 1979. Johnson had an average of 17.0 points, 7.9 rebounds, and 7.4 assists per game. In 1979 Johnson entered the draft and was drafted number one by the Los Angeles Lakers.

Mario Lemieux is a former ice hockey player. He played seventeen seasons in the NHL for the Pittsburgh Penguins. Lemieux was nicknamed _the Magnificent One_ and _Super Mario._ Lemieux was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame immediately after his retirement in 1997.

Michael Jordan is an American former basketball player. Jordan played a total of fifteen seasons in the NBA from1984 to 2003, with a few seasons off throughout. He played for the Washington Wizards and the Chicago Bulls. While he played for the Bulls, Jordan became a six time NBA champion, a six time NBA Finals Most Valuable Player, and a five time NBA Most Valuable Player. Jordan continues to be named the greatest basketball player of all time.

The Negro National League was established in Kansas City in 1920. The league originally consisted of eight professional teams. Although Black baseball leagues first existed in the 1880_s, many of them struggled and fizzled out. The league prospered for a few years, but ultimately fell apart in 1932 when World War II began.

Nolan Ryan is a former American baseball player who played for the New York Mets, the California Angels, the Houston Astros, and the Texas Rangers. Ryan was a pitcher throughout his 27 year career and consistently threw over 100 mph. He is an eleven-time strikeout leader, eight-time all star, and had his jersey retired for three different teams. Ryan currently holds the record for most no-hitters at seven and the most career strike outs at 5,714

Oscar De La Hoya is a Mexican-American former boxer. De La Hoya fought in six weight classes over his career, he won 39 out of 45 matches, and he won gold medals in the 1990 Goodwill Games in Seattle and a Gold in the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. He announced his retirement in 2009, after a sixteen-season career.

Oscar Robertson is an American former basketball player. He was nicknamed _Big O_ and played in the NBA from 1960 to 1974. He played for both the Cincinnati Royals and the Milwaukee Bucs over his career. Robertson is a twelve-time All Star, and NBA Most Valuable Player, and a three-time NBA All Star game Most Valuable Player.

Ozzie Smith is a former American baseball player. Smith played shortstop and was nicknamed _the Wizard._ He played his career for both the St. Louis Cardinals and the San Diego Padres. Smith is a fifteen time all star, a thirteen-time Gold Glove winner, and he set records for most double plays and assists.

Tillman played football for Arizona State University from 1994 to 1998. He was drafted as the 226th pick in the NFL draft by the Arizona Cardinals. Tillman was offered a 3.6 million dollar contract by the St. Louis Rams in 2002, but chose to enlist in the military instead.

Pat Tillman was an American football player who played in the NFL from 1998 to 2001 for the Arizona Cardinals. Tillman is renowned for his decision to leave the league and enlist in the military in lieu of the September 11th attacks. Tillman was killed by friendly fire on April 22, 2004 and has since become an icon in professional football.

Paul Anderson was an American weightlifter, power lifter, and strongman. Anderson was also an Olympic athlete as well and he won the gold medal in 1956 games in Melbourne. Anderson played a big role in legitimizing weightlifting as a sport.

Payne Stewart was an American golfer. He became a professional player in 1979 while he was still a student at Southern Methodist University. Stewart played until 1999 when he died in a plane accident. He ultimately won eleven PGA Tour events including two U.S. Open titles and two Open Championships.

Peyton Manning is an American former football player. He played from 1998 to 2015 and he played his entire career with both the Indianapolis Colts and the Denver Broncos. Manning played for the University of Tennessee and was drafted number one overall in the 1998 NFL draft. Manning is a two time Super Bowl champion, a fourteen time Pro Bowl selection, and a five time NFL Most Valuable Player.

Phil _Knucksie_ Niekro is an American former baseball player. He played from 1964 to 1987 for a total of twenty-four seasons. He played for the Milwaukee/Atlanta Braves, New York Yankees, Cleveland Indians, Toronto Blue Jays, and the Atlanta Braves. He is a five-time All Star, a five-time Gold Glove winner, and a Roberto Clemente award winner.

Ray Lewis is a former American football player. Lewis played his entire seventeen seasons with the Baltimore Ravens and is widely considered as the best Ravens players to play for the franchise. He is a two-time Super Bowl champion, a thirteen time Pro Bowl selection, and a two-time Defensive Player of the Year. _Ray Lewis.

Richard Petty is an American former NASCAR driver. Petty raced from 1958 to 1992 and was the first driver to win the NASCAR Cup Championship seven times. He won over 200 races over his career. Petty remains one of the most prominent and accomplished racers ever to engage in the sport.

Ricky Williams is an American former football player who played twelve seasons in the NFL. He played for the University of Texas and won the Heisman Trophy and he was drafted fifth overall by the New Orleans Saints. He played for five teams over his professional career and was selected to the Pro Bowl and became the Pro Bowl Most Valuable Player.
Location: Darrell K Royal-Texas Memorial Stadium at University of Texas, Austin

Description: Bobby Hull is a Canadian former ice hockey player. He played in the NHL for a total of twenty-three seasons and he played for the Winnipeg Jets, the Hartford Whalers, and the Chicago Black Hawks. He was the NHL_s Most Valuable Player twice, he won the Stanley Cup, and he was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1983.

Roberto Walker Clemente was a Puerto Rican baseball player. He played a total of eighteen seasons for the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1955 to 1972. He was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1973 and he was the first Latin American and Caribbean player to be included. Clemente was a fifteen time All Star, a two-time World Series champion, and a National League Most Valuable Player.

Rod Carew is a former American baseball player. Carew played first base and second base and eventually became a coach. He was an eighteen time all star, an American League Most Valuable Player, and an American League Rookie of the Year.

Roy Campanella was an American baseball player and he was primarily a catcher. He played for the Negro leagues and Mexican leagues until he entered the minor leagues in 1946. His career as a baseball player ended in 1958 when he was paralyzed in a car accident.
Location: National Baseball Hall of Fame Museum

Description: Sandy Koufax played for the Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers baseball franchise from 1955 to 1966. He is colloquially known as the Left Arm of God and is widely regarded as one of the best pitchers in baseball history.

Scottie Pippen is a former American basketball player. He played a total of seventeen seasons in the NBA and he was part of the Chicago Bulls team that won six NBA championships. Pippen was a seven time all star, a three time all NBA Fist Team selection, and an eight time NBA All-Defensive First Team.

Shaquille O_Neal is an American former basketball player. O_Neal played for a total of nineteen seasons for a total of six teams; the Orlando Magic, Los Angeles Lakers, Miami Heat, Phoenix Suns, Cleveland Cavaliers, and the Boston Celtics. O_Neal_s famed years came from his time on the Lakers where he helped win three NBA championship titles. He is a three time Final_s Most Valuable Player, a fifteen time All Star, and an NBA Most Valuable Player.

Shaquille O_Neal played basketball for Louisiana State University from 1989 to 1992. He was a three time all SEC player, a two time SEC all-defense selection, and a two time SEC player of the year. O_Neal was drafted in 1992 in the first round by the Orlando Magic.
Stan Mikita is a Canadian former ice hockey player. He played for the Chicago Black Hawks, who won the Stanley Cup in 1961. _Stan Mikita.

Steve Prefontaine was an American middle and long distance runner. He competed in the 1972 Olympics and won a gold medal in the 5000 meter at the Pan American games. He was tragically killed in an automobile accident in 1975 at the age of 24.

Ted Williams was an American baseball player who played from 1939 to 1960. He played all of his nineteen seasons with the Boston Red Sox as a left fielder. But like many baseball players of the time, World War II and military service upended Williams_ career. He is regarded as one of the best hitters of all time. He was a nineteen time all star, a two time American League Most Valuable Player, a four-time American League home run leader.

Terry Lee was an American athlete who competed successfully in the National Wheelchair Games. Lee competed in the pentathlon where he did the shot put, javelin, wheelchair sprint, swimming, and archery. Lee remained a supporter of differently abled people and was a large part of the YMCA_s Youth Wheelchair Sports Program.

The thoroughbred Park Sculptures are located in Lexington, Kentucky in Triangle Park. There a total of seven sculptures and each of them depict a famous racehorse and their jockey. The sculptures are arranged in a way that makes them look like they are in the middle of a race and they were erected in order to celebrate the rich equine history of Lexington.

Tim Tebow is an American baseball and football player. He played football for the University of Florida and won the Heisman trophy in 2007. The Denver Broncos drafted him in the first round that same year. Tebow is most famous for his touchdown celebration, which consisted of him taking a knee and thanking God.

Tommie Smith and John Carlos are two American former track and field athletes. Both of these men attended San Jose State University and were part of the track and field team where they competed in sprint events. Smith and Carlos became famous for their 1968 protests at the Mexico City Olympics. The two sprinters took first and third place in the 200 meter race and when they went to accept their medals, the raised their fists on the podium in protest of the mistreatment of Black Americans. Smith and Carlos continue to be outspoken supporters of civil right. 
 _1968 Olympics Black Power Salute.

Tony Gwynn was an American baseball player from 1982-2000. Gwynn played for the San Diego Padres club and was nicknamed _Mr. Padre._ Gwynn is known as one of the most consistent batters in MLB history. He was a fifteen time all star, five-time Golden Glove winner, and an eight time National League bating champion.

Ty Cobb is an American baseball player who played center field for the Detroit Tigers for twenty-two seasons. In 1936 Cobb received the most votes any player has gotten on a Hall of Fame ballot with 222 out of 226 votes. Cobb has been credited with setting over 90 MLB records during his career. Cobb holds the records for most home bases stolen, the record for youngest player ever to get 4,000 hits, and 2,000 runs.

Walter Johnson was an American baseball player. He played for twenty-one seasons for the Washington Senators, from 1907 to 1927. Johnson is still regarded as one of the best pitchers of all time and he set many pitching records that still remain unbroken today. He is a twelve-time All Star, a two-time American League Most Valuable Player, and holds the MLB record for 110 strikeouts.

Warren Spahn was an American baseball player who played his entire twenty-one year career with teams in the National League. Spahn was a pitcher, a seventeen time all star, and a World Series champion. In 1942, During World War II, Spahn enlisted in the military and did not return to baseball until 1946.

William Beck Nicholson was an American former baseball player. He played in the MLB from 1936 to 1953 for the Philadelphia Athletics, Chicago Cubs, and the Philadelphia Phillies. Nicholson is a five-time All Star, a two-time National League Home Run leader, and a two-time National League RBI leader. 
 _Bill Nicholson (Baseball).

Willie Mays is a former American baseball player. He played for the New York and San Francisco Giants and the New York Mets from 1951 to 1973. He is regarded as one of the best baseball player of all time and was selected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1979. Mays is a 24 time all star, a two time National League Most Valuable Player, and a twelve time Gold Glove Award.

Willie McCovey was an American baseball player. He was the first baseman for the San Francisco Giants; he also played for the San Diego Padres, and the Oakland Athletics. McCovey was a six time all star, a Rookie of the year, and three-time National League homerun leader._Willie McCovey.

Willie Stargell was an American baseball player. He played from 1962 to 1982 and he played his whole career for the Pittsburgh Pirates. Stargell was a seven time all star, a two-time World Series champion, and a World Series Most Valuable Player.

Wilma Rudolph was an American former sprinter and track and field athlete. In the 1960s Rudolph was dubbed the fastest woman in the world and she became the first American woman to win three Olympic gold medals in a single Olympics at the 1960 games in Rome. Rudolph was an ardent civil rights activist who fought to have her home coming parade in Clarksville, Tennessee, integrated.

Wilt Chamberlain was an American basketball player. He played for the Philadelphia/San Francisco Warriors and the Los Angeles Lakers over his fourteen-year career. Chamberlain holds records for rebounds and scoring and is still the only player to ever score one hundred points in a single game. Chamberlain is regarded as one of the best players to play the game; he is a two-time NBA champion, a thirteen time All Star, and a seven time NBA scoring champion.

Young Corbet III, born Ralph Giordano, was an Italian-born American boxer. Corbet was the World Welterwight champion in 1933, he was inducted into the Italian American Sports Hall of Fame in 1982, and the International Boxing Hall of Fame in 2004.
